Arduino Color Sorter

  • Purpose

    The purpose of this project was to create a system that would sort Skittles based on color. Two micro servo motors were used in the project; one to pick up the Skittles, and one to drop them into designated cups. A TCS230 color sensor was used to read color. Red, green, and yellow skittles were sorted and dropped into corresponding cups.

  • Micro Controller

    The Arduino Uno is a microcontroller that is responsible for commanding the two servos and the color sensor. The Arduino has digital input/output pins and analog pins that are responsible for sending and receiving data. The arduino is powered via a USB port.

  • Micro Servo Motors

    Two micro servo motors were used in this project. One was attached to a circular rotating platform designed to pick a Skittle up from an entry tube. The servo then positioned the Skittle underneath the sensor where color determination occurred. Lastly, The Skittle was dropped onto the slide where it would fall into a desired cup. The second servo was responsible for properly angling the slide.

  • TCS230 Color Sensor

    The color sensor contains 64 photodiodes, evenly distributed as red, green, blue and clear which are responsible for color readings. The TCS230's readings are converted from current to frequency allowing the Arduino to differentiate between skittle color. A website that assisted my understanding of the TCS230 can be found here.

  • Framework

    The frame was built out of scrap wood that I cut, hand sanded and drilled together. The rotating platform was hand made and fitted to one of the servos. It was designed to pickup skittles from the entry pipe (part of rubber hosing) and bring them directly underneath the color sensor. They were then transported to a drilled hole in the shelf where they would fall onto the slide, which was designed using the back of a drywall corner bead.

  • Coding

    The program to control this robot was written in the Arduino IDE using the programming language C/C++. The Servo.h library was included to control the two micro servos. Two micro servo objects were created, one for the job of picking up the skittles, and the other for setting the path towards a certain cup. The micro servos were controlled using the write() function that would turn the servos based on the degree amount inputted. The TCS230 color sensor was utilized by using the pulseIn() function that would read the output frequency detected by the sensor. These values were then inserted into three different if statements (one for red, green, and yellow) that would determine skittle color based on pre-determined frequency numbers that corresponded to each color. A link to my github repository for this code is below.

    Github

  • Challenges

    Throughout this project I faced two significant issues. The first was the inability of the Arduino to accurately differentiate color. This was result of color frequencies being too similar. To remedy, I continually adjusted the distance between the platform and the sensor allowing more variety in frequency numbers to occur. The Arduino could now distinguish between different colors.

    The second problem was getting the entry tube for the skittles to reliably work. I originally had a transparent piece of tubing, however, the diameter of the tube was approximately a 1/8" larger than that of a skittle. This extra room allowed skittles to topple to the sides of each other, resulting in them getting stuck. After experimenting with various diameters, I eventually found a size which functioned dependably.
